questions.text: Hemochromatosis is an inherited disorder that, over time, can lead to:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of the above Hemochromatosis is an inherited disorder of iron metabolism that results in a progressive increase in hepatic iron deposition . Over time, it can lead to portal-based fibrosis progressing to cirrhosis, liver failure, and hepatocellular cancer.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Hemochromatosis is False?

options.label: C
options.text: Excessive iron deposition in parenchymal cells

options.label: D
options.text: Potentially leading to fibrosis and organ failure

questions.correct_answer: B. Increase in production of hepcidin
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Increase in production of hepcidin Hemochromatosis is an iron-storage disorder with genetic heterogeneity but with a final common metabolic pathway resulting in inappropriately low production of the hormone hepcidin. Hepcidin is regulator of iron absorption . (“ HEP atic bacteri CID al prote IN ”) It has both antifungal and antibacterial activity. Hepcidin exerts its antimicrobial action by restricting serum iron . Total body iron stores, Hypoxia, and inflammation regulate it. Iron gets absorbed as Fe 2+. The storage form of iron is Fe 3+. It leaves the cell through ferroportin and gets converted to Fe 2+ . Now this is bound to transferrin and goes to the marrow for erythropoiesis. Ferroportin is controlled by Hepcidin which is released by the liver. HFEgene controls the expression of Hepcidin . HFE gene mutation leads to the absence of Hepcidin —>no regulation of Ferroportin —---uncontrolled absorption leading to iron overload and deposition in tissues.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A, C: An increase in intestinal iron absorption and the deposition of excessive amounts of iron in parenchymal cells with eventual tissue damage and organ failure. Option: D: Hemochromatosis now refers to a group of genetic diseases predisposing to iron overload, potentially leading to fibrosis and organ failure. Cirrhosis of the liver, diabetes mellitus, arthritis, cardiomyopathy, and hypogonadotropic hypogonadism are the major clinical manifestations.

questions.text: Which of the following is less expensive, more convenient, and safer for managing patients with hemochromatosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Phlebotomy Phlebotomy is also less expensive, more convenient, and safer for most patients. Iron removal is best accomplished weekly or, with gross iron loading, twice-weekly phlebotomy of 500 mL. One 500-mL unit of blood contains 200–250 mg of iron , and ≥25 g of iron may have to be removed. Therefore, in patients with advanced disease, weekly phlebotomy may be required for 1–2 years, and it should be continued until the serum ferritin level is ≤100 μg/L. After that, are performed at appropriate intervals to maintain ferritin levels at ≤100 μg/L

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Chelating agents such as deferoxamine, when given parenterally, remove 10–20 mg of iron per day , which is much less than that mobilized by once-weekly phlebotomy. These are indicated when anemia or hypoproteinemia is severe enough to preclude Option: C. An effective oral iron chelating agent, deferasirox (Exjade), is now available. This agent is effective in thalassemia and secondary iron overload but is expensive and carries the risk of significant side effects. Option: D. Blood transfusion increases iron load and worsens the disease.

Extraedge:

Arthritis and Hypogonadism do not improve with Phlebotomy.

questions.text: A 32-year male diagnosed with Hemochromatosis is planned for repeated phlebotomy. Which of the following is NOT true about the outcome of this treatment modality?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pigmentation of skin increases With repeated Phlebotomy, pigmentation of the skin decreases.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A, B, C: Life expectancy is improved by removing the excessive iron stores and maintaining these stores at near-normal levels. With repeated phlebotomy, the liver decreases in size, liver function improves, skin pigmentation decreases, and cardiac failure may be reversed. Joint manifestations and gonad manifestations do not reverse after Phlebotomy . Hepatic fibrosis may decrease, but established cirrhosis is irreversible.

questions.text: Mr. Suresh complains of pain in his fingers for two months, dark patches over his hands for one month, and loss of libido for three weeks. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hemochromatosis The association of Dark patches over the hands (skin pigmentation), pain in the fingers( arthritis), and loss of libido(hypogonadism) should suggest the diagnosis of hemochromatosis. Presents with Slate gray skin pigmentation (due to excess melanin and iron deposition in basal layers) occurs especially in exposed parts, arthritis, especially of 2nd and 3rd MCP joint , HPA involved due to deposition of iron. Other clinical features include liver cirrhosis, diabetes mellitus, arrhythmias, and cardiomyopathy.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. - Ectopic ACTH does not present with loss of libido or arthritis. Option: B. - Wilson’s disease does not present with loss of libido, arthritis, or hyperpigmentation. Option: D. - Rheumatoid arthritis does not present with loss of libido or hyperpigmentation.

questions.text: A patient presents with hyperpigmentation of the skin, FBS - 190 mg/dl, USG abdomen shows nodular liver surface, round edge, hypoechoic nodules in the liver parenchyma. What is the inheritance of this clinical picture?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

A The given clinical picture is suggestive of hemochromatosis To start reading a pedigree Determine whether the trait is Dominant or Recessive –if the feature is dominant, one of the parents must have the quality. Dominant traits will not skip a generation. If the attribute is recessive, neither parent must have the feature since they can be heterozygous. Determine if the chart shows an Autosomal or Sex-linked trait. For example, males are much more commonly affected by X Linked recessive traits than females. In autosomal Traits, males and females are equally likely to be involved. Hemochromatosis has AR inheritance. Features of AR Inheritance Males and females have the same chance of expressing the trait; one can tell the attribute if HE/she is If both parents express the trait, all their offspring should say it. If offspring express the trait, but their parents don't, then both parents are heterozygous. If one parent expresses the trait, then their offspring who don't speak are heterozygous . The marker can skip generations.

questions.text: Mr. Raju, aged 52 years, who is a known case of diabetes, develops cirrhosis. There is associated skin hyperpigmentation and restrictive cardiomyopathy. Which of the following is the best initial test to diagnose this case?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Transferrin saturation The clinical presentation of diabetes with cirrhosis, skin pigmentation, and cardiac involvement in restrictive cardiomyopathy suggests the possibility of hemochromatosis. Transferrin saturation =Serumiron/TIBC X100 It is the most sensitive and specific test for hemochromatosis. Ferritin levels are increased in hemochromatosis. It can also be raised in other conditions as it is an acute phase reactant. Liver biopsy is done in cases with serum Ferritin>1000 ng/ml. The amount of Iron can be quantified by Perl Prussian blue stain. In HFE-related disease, Hepatocytes are involved . Kupffer Cells are not affected.
